August 12, 1984: Fiction
''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Putnam,
$19.95.) Life in an Ohio town, 1868 to 1932.
LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $19.95.) Fictionalized account of the
Civil War Presidency.
FIRST AMONG EQUALS, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press/Simon & Schuster,
$16.95.) Three young men vie to be chosen Prime Minister by the Queen of
England.
FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The relationship of a
mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years.
THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.)
A lawyer is caught in a conspiracy to seize the Western world.
THE BUTTER BATTLE BOOK, by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $6.95.) A warning
about the nuclear arms race in words and pictures.
DEEP SIX, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) One man copes with a
sinister Asian shipping family and an even more threatening Soviet plot.
THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $17.95.) One man's experience in the bloody
wars of the Holy Land.
THE WALKING DRUM, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $15.95.) A young man from
Brittany sets out to free his father, enslaved in 12th-century Asia.
THE GREMLINS STORYBOOK, by Mary Carey. (Golden Books, $6.95.)
Illustrated storybook based on the current film ''Gremlins.''
THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE, by Susan Howatch. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.)
The legends of an old manor haunt four generations of an English family.
THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK, by John Updike. (Knopf, $15.95.) Three witches
wreak havoc in a contemporary Rhode Island town.
MACHINE DREAMS, by Jayne Anne Phillips. (Seymour Lawrence/Dutton,
$16.95.) Small, ordinary moments in a family's life burst into unexpected
meanings.
HERETICS OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam, $16.95.) The fifth volume of a
series about life on a faraway planet.
POSSESSIONS, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon Press/Simon & Schuster, $16.95.)
A woman discovers the truth about her husband after he disappears.
August 12, 1984
Non-Fiction
THE KENNEDYS: An American Drama, by Peter Collier and David Horowitz.
(Summit, $20.95.) The dark as well as the glamorous side of four generations of a
prominent family.
WIRED, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The troubled life of the
late entertainer John Belushi.
IN GOD'S NAME, by David A. Yallop. (Bantam, $16.95.) A British journalist argues
that Pope John Paul I's death in 1978 was a case of murder.
THE NIGHTMARE YEARS: 1930-1940, by William L. Shirer. (Little, Brown,
$22.50.) Second volume of the memoirs of a celebrated foreign correspondent.
GOOD MORNING, MERRY SUNSHINE, by Bob Greene. (Atheneum, $14.95.)
The syndicated columnist's journal of his child's first year.
ONE WRITER'S BEGINNINGS, by Eudora Welty. (Harvard, $10.) The novelist
recalls her childhood in Mississippi.
THE FIRE FROM WITHIN, by Carlos Castaneda. (Simon & Schuster, $16.50.)
Another report on the world of magic and sorcery.
MOTHERHOOD: The Second Oldest Profession, by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-
Hill, $12.95.) A humorous look at the biggest on-the-job training program ever.
THE MARCH OF FOLLY, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $18.95.) The blunders
of government in four periods, from Troy to Vietnam.
FIRST LADY FROM PLAINS, by Rosalynn Carter. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.)
Memoirs.
D.V., by Diana Vreeland. Edited by George Plimpton and Christopher Hemphill.
(Knopf, $15.95.) Memoirs of the one-time ''Empress of Fashion.''
POWERPLAY, by Mary Cunningham with Fran Schumer. (Linden Press/Simon &
Schuster, $16.95.) The rise and fall of a woman executive at the Bendix
Corporation.
REGGIE, by Reggie Jackson with Mike Lupica. (Villard Books, $15.95.) The
autobiography of the controversial baseball player.
BALLS, by Graig Nettles and Peter Golenbock. (Putnam, $14.95.) The San Diego
third baseman tells about his life with the New York Yankees.
PAST IMPERFECT, by Joan Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The
autobiography of the star of the ''Dynasty'' television series.
